_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Versum Materials US, LLC.
Hometown Electronics Specialty Gases Facility

  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

Versum Materials strictly adheres to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations such as OSHA PSM .  Versum Materials release prevention program includes process system design utilizing automated shutdowns/interlocks, operating procedures, equipment testing and inspections, safety devices (e.g., alarms, cameras, instrumentation, relief devices) that are inherent in the design of this facility.  
Safe work practices, training programs, a formal hazard recognition program, robust incident investigations and Management of Change process,  and routine safety meetings/discussions  with personnel supplement the inherent safe design of the plants.

Versum Materials emergency response program is based upon the OSHA HAZWOPER regulation.  This facility has an employee staffed emergency response team and the emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire authority and Local Emergency Planning Committee to ensure appropriate measures can be taken by local emergency responders to assist in controlling accidental releases.

 The stationary source and regulated substances handled:

The primary products of this facility are specialty and electronic gases and chemicals.  A majority of these gases are derived from fluorine, which is generated at the site in electrolytic cells by electrical decomposition of hydrogen fluoride.  Hydrogen is generated as a by-product, which is vented in small amounts to the atmosphere . After impurities are removed, the fluorine gas is compressed for distribution to the various fluorine users throughout the facility.  

The hydrogen fluoride is brought on site by railcar and the rail cars are placed inside a totally enclosed containment building for unloading that includes a scrubber for the exhaust air from the building.  The hydrogen fluoride is then f

ed directly from the railcar to a fluorine plant or to NF3 reactors.  While the containment building can accommodate 2 connected railcars, additional railcars are staged outside of the building.  Due to the long and inconsistent lead time for delivery of rail cars, at times more than two (2) cars are maintained on-site to ensure the raw material is always available.  Unloading only occurs from rail cars located inside the building.

The fluorine is also used to make a 20% fluorine in Nitrogen mix which is filled into cylinders and ISO trailers. Cylinders are stored within the shipping/receiving area while ISO trailers are stored within designated storage areas. 

Anhydrous ammonia is brought on site by tank truck and pumped into a stationary storage tank.  It is used as a raw material in the production of nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).  NF3 is made by introducing fluorine gas into ammonium bifluoride.  Anhydrous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank, vaporized, and fed to the NF3 reactors to control the hydrogen fluoride concentration in the product, and to replenish the ammonium bifluoride.  Anhydrous ammonia is also fed to a purification plant, where moisture is removed before it is re-packaged into other bulk containers. The packaged bulk containers are stored adjacent to the purification plant or designated locations within the facility.

Aqueous ammonia is generated from off gas in the ammonia production facility.

Arsine is manufactured onsite from various raw materials. Finished cylinders are stored in production facility and within our shipping/receiving area.  

Phosphine cylinders are filled at other locations and brought to the site where the external valve of the package is cleaned and the cylinders stored in our shipping/receiving area. 

Anhydrous hydrogen chloride ISO containers are filled at other locations and brought onsite to be trans filled into smaller containers. Cylinders and ISO containers are stored in shipping/receiving area as well as desig

nated ISO storage areas onsite. 

Dichlorosilane cylinders are filled at other locations and are stored in our shipping/receiving area.

Chlorine cylinders are filled at other locations and stored in the shipping/receiving and Compounds production area(s).


 The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps:

The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental Release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  


5-Year Accident History

Versum Materials has reported two (2) accidental releases* which have occurred in the last 5-years.
*Accidents include events in which precautionary first aid was administered. 

The emergency response program:

The facility complies with all EPA, OSHA, and Compressed Gas Association requirements for emergency response and follows NIMS Incident Command Structure . Plant operators are trained to respond/mitigate releases at their unit. When notified via plant-wide emergency notification system employees that are members of the on-site emergency response team will respond to emergencies before initiating emergency response from outside agencies. Incident Command will initiate calls for outside agency assistance if needed.  
The facility maintains an Emergency Procedure Manual that contains specific procedures for employees to take in the event of an emergency or accidental release. This information also contains the names and numbers of responding outside agencies.  


 Planned changes to improve safety:

The facility resolves recommendations from Process Hazards Analysis and Near Miss Incident Investigations, some of which may result in modifications to the plant design and operating procedures.  It also strives toward continuous improvement with regards to EH&S and Recognized And Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practice and design.  Versum Materials US, LLC. has implemented Company EH&S Global standards and best practices that often exce
